Headline.Para: BT EXCLUSIVE; Bittersweet taste of food delivery apps

Snippet.Para: Business is growing but restaurants say commissions are a big dent on margins; dining-in still accounts for most sales at partner eateries

ReplyItem.Byline: Neo Shi Wei , Bittersweet taste of food delivery apps

Headline.Para: BT EXCLUSIVE; Bittersweet taste of food delivery apps

LeadPara.Para: Business is growing but restaurants say commissions are a big dent on margins; dining-in still accounts for most sales at partner eateries

TailParas.Para: NEWS of the merger of Grab and Uber cast the spotlight on food delivery apps here, but like the ride hailing industry, the online food delivery business also suffers from fierce competition and likely lower value and margins.

Restaurants that use the service tell The Business Times that the fast-growing phenomenon can account for up to 10 per cent of total revenue, but the cost of the incremental business comes at a price - squeezed margins.
Many eateries believe food delivery apps are here to stay, adding that numbers aside, players like foodpanda and Deliveroo offer them brand visibility and useful data.
Since foodpanda first started in Singapore in 2012, a slew of food delivery apps have followed, notably Deliveroo, honestbee and Uber Eats.

There are recent shifts in the market too, with Grab announcing it will acquire the operations of Uber Eats on Monday, as part of the Grab-Uber merger. This will allow Grab to expand its existing GrabFood businesses in Indonesia and Thailand to Singapore.

So far, foodpanda and Deliveroo appear to be the industry leaders, with deliveries from 3,800 restaurants and 3,500 respectively. Within the past year, food and beverage (F&B) brands that have jumped on the bandwagon include Crystal Jade Kitchen, Aloha Poke and Ben & Jerry's.
In terms of revenue contribution, Restaurant Association of Singapore president Vincent Tan said: "Some companies do see significant revenue gain due to the additional sales channel."

"There are also others who are of the opinion that the gain in revenue is insufficient to cover the additional costs - commission to the delivery company, increase in rental due to increase in revenue." Many food & beverage outlets pay a fixed rent plus a percentage of sales to their landlord.

Among the restaurants that were more forthcoming, Sawadee Thai Cuisine said food delivery apps make up about 10 per cent of its total revenue, same as the previous year, while local burger joint BurgerUP sees about 5 per cent on average.
Lim Li-Wei, chief executive of Japanese restaurant cluster Emporium Shokuhin said food deliveries make up 3 to 6 per cent of total sales.
Singapore Exchange-listed food companies Jumbo Group and Japan Food Holdings told BT the contribution has been "small" as only some of their F&B brands are currently involved.

Euromonitor International research analyst Chayadi Karim said the average commission eateries have to pay the food delivery companies is around 20-30 per cent, adding that "to some restaurant owners, the prospect of reaching out to more customers is not worth the hefty margins they have to sacrifice".
BT understands that some food delivery apps charge higher rates for restaurants whose average food value is lower.
Given the commissions they have to pay, several restaurants avoid cannibalising their dine-in business by offering deliveries only from outlets that have poor footfall.

What do consumers themselves make of the explosion in food delivery services? DBS analyst Alfie Yeo said: "People continue to have the lifestyle to go to the restaurants to eat . . . this is not changing."

RHB Research Institute Singapore analyst Juliana Cai said: "Although the food may be the same, dining at the restaurant offers a whole different experience that includes the ambience and the level of service given."
Nonetheless, restaurants acknowledged that food delivery is a growing trend, and the partnership with food delivery apps gives other benefits.

Takahashi Kenichi, executive chairman and chief executive of Japan Food Holdings, which operates brands like Ajisen Ramen, said revenue contribution from deliveries is still very small. "But we recognise that food delivery is a fast growing segment we cannot ignore as it targets a group of customers who may not wish to dine out but still want to enjoy our food in the comfort of their home."
Representatives from food delivery apps pointed out that on top of providing an additional source of customers, their data-driven service adds value for restaurants.

An Uber Eats spokesman said: "With our Restaurant Manager tool, our restaurant partners are also able to access insights about their service quality, customer satisfaction... dig into feedback and information that result in data-driven decisions to improve their business."

Siddharth Shanker, general manager of Deliveroo Singapore, said its initiatives like Frank - a predictive logarithmal aimed at boosting efficiency of the entire delivery process - has been able to cut meal delivery time by 15 per cent since it was introduced earlier last year.
Some restaurants also view the food delivery apps as a way to increase brand awareness.

Ana Lei, head of marketing at ABR Holdings, which owns and operates Swensen's in Singapore, said: "Swensen's sees partnering with food delivery companies more like a marketing tool as it reaches out to a new group of customers. We are trying to reach consumers who may not have dined at Swensen's before."

Lester Gan, general manager of BurgerUP, said: "Being featured on the food delivery app informs potential customers of our presence and location; even if they do not order from us through the delivery app, they know where to find us."
For now, restaurants say there is no turning back.
Soup Restaurant said it invested less than S$30,000 to launch their own delivery platform in January, to complement their tie-up with foodpanda and Deliveroo.
But most other restaurants said they will stick to existing external food delivery apps, with some seeking other delivery apps to further broaden their consumer base.

Vegetarian eatery chain Greendot, for example, is working with Oddle. William Ngan, general manager of Greendot, said: "For Oddle, we have mini sets that cater to smaller families or colleagues to dine in at their office or home."

So where's the food delivery industry headed? RHB's Ms Cai said: "Restaurants with idle capacity would likely partner with more apps to ramp up their utilisation. On the other hand, the onus is on the external food delivery companies to partner with popular restaurants to raise their profiles and customer usage."

Article.Byline: Neo Shi Wei , Bittersweet taste of food delivery apps
Article.Art: Restaurants acknowledge that food delivery is a growing trend, and the partnership with food delivery apps also gives non-monetary benefits.
